Guild Thrills Crowd

When the Jays came on the field
to resume play ill the second half,
they looked like a different crowd.
They now seemed to have the pep
which they lacked during the early
stages of the game. The one outstanding- play which thrilled the
crowd of about 1,500 fans and
brought them to their feet with
lusty cheers and applause, came in
the third quarter when Loren Guild,
Hopkins quarterback, after making
a spectacular one-handed interception of a long forward pass by Bryant, ran 65 yards through the whole
Randolph-Macon te* to deposit
the ball behind the goal-line for
Hopkins' first score. The run was
a good one, but it was only made
possible by the combined efforts of
the whole Jay team. Every man
realized what he must do to make
the most of this opportunity and,
gathering fast they formed beautiful
interference for their quarterback
and cut down the Yellow Jackets
one by one, thus affording Guild a
narrow passage down the west side
of the field. The Jays tried to kick
the ball over the goal posts for the
extra point, but failed.
Threaten Jay Goal

This play seemed to arouse the
fighting spirit in both teams. Randolph-Macon recovered and started.
down the field toward the Blue Jay
goal. By a series of beautiful overthe-line passes, accompanied by a
few line-bucks, the Yellow Jackets
worked the ball down the field to
the Jay 25-yard line. The Jays dug
their cleats deep into the ground
and forced their opponents to lose
the ball on downs.
Jays Score Again

Here Hopkins started a fierce
offensive that coundn't be stopped.
Jack Turnbull tucked the pig skin
under his arm and ran around the
left end for a 20-yard gain. A few
completed passes, coupled with a
series of off-tackle plays placed the
ball on the Yellow Jackets' 20-yard
line. A penalty put the ball on the
five-yard line and on the second play
Turnbull went over for a touchdown. Bledsoe drop-kicked for the
extra point.

realized what he must do to make

gathering fast they formed beautiful
interference for their quarterback

narrow passage down the west side

extra point, but failed.

their cleats deep into the ground
and forced their opponents to lose
the ball on downs.

ball on the Yellow Jackets' 20-yard
line. A penalty put the ball on the
five-yard line and on the second play

extra point.
